sourceDesc.p: This is the feature-file for the genitive exponent.

revisionDesc.change: For EGY-___ there are no values found

item.label: mtāʕ, mtāʕat, mtāwaʕ, ntāʕ, ntāʕat, ntawaʕ
m. giyy, f. gīt-, pl. giyyāt-
m. šiyy- f. šīt-, pl. šiyyāt-
z+noun
item.desc: ex. z-mayy suxni (of the hot water)

wib:featureValueObservation.note: f. taʕīt, pl. taʕūl, taʕīn
"The attested forms are tabaʕ, tabʕit, tabʕīt, and tabʕūl" (Agbaht 2023:128).
f. gīt-, pl. giyyāt- (Behnstedt and Geva-Kleinberger 2019:269)
f. tabaʕt/tabʕat/tabʕit/tabaʕīt, pl. tabaʕūn/tabʕīn/tabaʕōn. (Behnstedt and Geva-Kleinberger 2019:269)
f. tabaʕt/tabʕat/tabʕit/tabaʕīt, pl. tabaʕūn/tabʕīn/tabaʕōn. (Behnstedt and Geva-Kleinberger 2019:269)
f. tabaʕt/tabʕat/tabʕit/tabaʕīt, pl. tabaʕūn/tabʕīn/tabaʕōn. (Behnstedt and Geva-Kleinberger 2019:269)
f. šāt-, pl. šiyyāt-. (Behnstedt and Geva-Kleinberger 2019:269)
Šēl is a Hebrew loanword. (Behnstedt and Geva-Kleinberger 2019:269)
No etymology is indicated, for a discussion see WAD IV, map 472. Might be Syriac. (Behnstedt and Geva-Kleinberger 2019:269)
f. tabaʕt/tabʕat/tabʕit/tabaʕīt, pl. tabaʕūn/tabʕīn/tabaʕōn. (Behnstedt and Geva-Kleinberger 2019:269)
f. gīt-, pl. giyyāt- (Behnstedt and Geva-Kleinberger 2019:269)
f. šīt-, pl. šiyyāt-. (Behnstedt and Geva-Kleinberger 2019:269)
f. tabaʕt/tabʕat/tabʕit/tabaʕīt, pl. tabaʕūn/tabʕīn/tabaʕōn. (Behnstedt and Geva-Kleinberger 2019:269)
f. tabaʕt/tabʕat/tabʕit/tabaʕīt, pl. tabaʕūn/tabʕīn/tabaʕōn. (Behnstedt and Geva-Kleinberger 2019:269)
f. taʕt- pl.m taʕūn- pl.f. taʕāt-. (Behnstedt and Geva-Kleinberger 2019:269)
f. tabaʕt/tabʕat/tabʕit/tabaʕīt, pl. tabaʕūn/tabʕīn/tabaʕōn. (Behnstedt and Geva-Kleinberger 2019:269)
f. tabaʕt/tabʕat/tabʕit/tabaʕīt, pl. tabaʕūn/tabʕīn/tabaʕōn. (Behnstedt and Geva-Kleinberger 2019:269)
f. tabaʕt/tabʕat/tabʕit/tabaʕīt, pl. tabaʕūn/tabʕīn/tabaʕōn. (Behnstedt and Geva-Kleinberger 2019:269)
f. gīt-, pl. giyyāt- (Behnstedt and Geva-Kleinberger 2019:269)
f. tabaʕt/tabʕat/tabʕit/tabaʕīt, pl. tabaʕūn/tabʕīn/tabaʕōn. (Behnstedt and Geva-Kleinberger 2019:269)
f. tabaʕt/tabʕat/tabʕit/tabaʕīt, pl. tabaʕūn/tabʕīn/tabaʕōn. (Behnstedt and Geva-Kleinberger 2019:269)
f. taʕt- pl.m taʕūn- pl.f. taʕāt-. (Behnstedt and Geva-Kleinberger 2019:269)
f. tabaʕt/tabʕat/tabʕit/tabaʕīt, pl. tabaʕūn/tabʕīn/tabaʕōn. (Behnstedt and Geva-Kleinberger 2019:269)
f. tabaʕt/tabʕat/tabʕit/tabaʕīt, pl. tabaʕūn/tabʕīn/tabaʕōn. (Behnstedt and Geva-Kleinberger 2019:269)

"Although the particle tabaʕ occurs in Baskinta it is not as common as in other Lebanese dialects. Tabaʕ occurs with inanimate objects only and it is commonly used when referring to possessions such as property." (Haidar 1979:122)
f. tabʕit, pl. tabʕīn or tabʕūn. (Jiha 1964:164)
The genitive exponents cannot be used to refer to personal relations or parts of the body (e.g. my eyes, my wife). (Jiha 1964:164) (
f. mtääʕit, pl. mtääʕīn. (Jiha 1964:164)
The genitive exponents cannot be used to refer to personal relations or parts of the body (e.g. my eyes, my wife). (Jiha 1964:164) (
f.tabʕit, pl. tabʕūn or tabʕīn. (Schukro 2004:96)
Found seldom and only among old speakers. (Schukro 2004:96)
f. tabʕūlt- , pl. tabʕūlēt-.
f. gīt-
Talay (1999:170-171) notes that the genitive exponent is rarely used and that the form tabaʕ has almost replaced other forms like gī, hnīt and šīt. The Khawētna in Iraq use māl.
The author does not specify if the genitive exponent is inflected or not.
Also the relatve pronoun is lay. (Lahdo 2009: 86)

No information on the inflectional properties of mtāʕ
māl is inflected for the feminine - mālat
māl is inflected for the feminine - mālat
The Baḥārna prefer māl over ḥagg (Holes 2016:104)
māl is inflected for the feminine - mālat

māl is restriced to the northern dialects within Naǧd
This is mainly used by rural (sedenatary and pastoral) and urban-pastoral speakers
This is mainly used by rural (sedenatary and pastoral) speakers
This is mainly used by urban and urban-pastoral speakers
This is mainly used by urban speakers who are influenced by the Egyptian dialect

cit.quote: We throw away only the water of the curdled milk

wib:featureValueObservation.note: This urban particle is used mainly by early urbanised Baggara (Manfredi 2013:36)

This is a recent borrowing from Egyptian Arabic

cit.quote: it is mine, it isnt't yours

wib:featureValueObservation.note: ntāʕ is more marginally employed than mtāʕ
tāʕ is more marginally employed than mtāʕ

cit.quote: xde dǝftar mtāʕ wuld u ktǝb fīh xuṛṛāfa
he took a boy's notebook and wrote a story

mostly direct annexation
only inflected in plural, not gender
only inflected in plural, not gender
synthetic genitive only in fixed phrases
(m)taʕ used only by older people
under Uzbek influence, the modifier may as well precede the head, which in this case carries a referential pronominal suffix, e.g. adami rāsu ‘the man's head’
if infelcted, only plural form is used

"Cypriot Arabic also utilizes a special genitive construction specifically with inalienable nouns, principally kinship terms, entailing the possessive marker l- preceded by an proleptic pronoun: Cypriot Arabic yapatu l-yorko ‘George's father’. On the Aramaic origin of this trait, see Blanc (1964:130); observe the close parallel in Central Neo-Aramaic where it is generally restricted to a small class of nominals comprising inalienables and temporal expressions: əšmé-d-ḥoṯux ‘your sister's name’, barṯé-d-ʿamti ‘my paternal cousin’, etc." EALL
under Uzbek influence, the modifier may as well precede the head, which in this case carries a referential pronominal suffix, e.g. adami rāsu ‘the man's head’
mataʕ or mata
mataʕ or mata
taʕ and its derived forms are used mosly
direct annexation is used in fixed terms and also with the word mul "owner"
hagg + personal pronoun suffix, walad hagg-i 'my son'
hagg + personal pronoun suffix, walad hagg-i 'my son'
hagg + personal pronoun suffix, walad hagg-i 'my son'
+ personal pronoun suffix
+ personal pronoun suffix
long form dyal is mostly used with pronouns to indicate possession
